canonical_explanation.text: Motion is the change in position of an object with respect to time and its surroundings. Distance is the total path length covered by an object (scalar quantity), while displacement is the shortest distance between the initial and final positions (vector quantity). Speed is distance per unit time and velocity is displacement per unit time. When an object covers equal distances in equal intervals of time, the motion is uniform; otherwise it is non-uniform. Acceleration is the rate of change of velocity. The three equations of motion for uniformly accelerated motion are: v = u + at, s = ut + ½at², and v² = u² + 2as. Distance-time and velocity-time graphs help visualize motion. In uniform circular motion, an object moves along a circular path with constant speed but changing velocity due to continuous change in direction.
rules: Distance is a scalar quantity; displacement is a vector quantity.
Speed = Distance / Time; Velocity = Displacement / Time.
Uniform motion: equal distances in equal time intervals.
Non-uniform motion: unequal distances in equal time intervals.
First equation of motion: v = u + at.
Second equation of motion: s = ut + ½at².
Third equation of motion: v² = u² + 2as.
Slope of distance-time graph gives speed.
Slope of velocity-time graph gives acceleration.
Area under velocity-time graph gives distance.
In uniform circular motion, speed is constant but velocity changes.

questions.question_text: What is the SI unit of displacement?
questions.explanation_correct: The SI unit of displacement is the metre (m). Displacement measures the shortest distance between two points and, like all lengths in the SI system, is measured in metres.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Kilometre and centimetre are units of length but not the SI unit. Second is the unit of time, not displacement. The SI unit of displacement is the metre (m).

questions.question_text: Which of the following is a scalar quantity?
questions.explanation_correct: Distance is a scalar quantity because it has only magnitude and no direction. It measures the total path length covered by an object regardless of direction.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Displacement, velocity, and acceleration are all vector quantities because they have both magnitude and direction. Distance is the only scalar quantity listed here.

questions.question_text: An object moves 5 m east and then 5 m west. What is the displacement?
questions.explanation_correct: Displacement is the shortest distance from the initial to the final position. Since the object returns to its starting point, the displacement is 0 m, even though the distance covered is 10 m.
questions.explanation_incorrect: 10 m is the total distance covered, not the displacement. The displacement is 0 m because the object returned to its starting position. Displacement considers only the net change in position.

questions.question_text: Displacement can be:
questions.explanation_correct: Displacement is a vector quantity that can be positive (in the chosen reference direction), negative (opposite to the reference direction), or zero (when the object returns to its starting position).
questions.explanation_incorrect: Displacement is not limited to only positive, only negative, or only zero values. As a vector quantity, it can take any of these values depending on the direction and extent of motion relative to the starting point.

questions.question_text: Speed is defined as:
questions.explanation_correct: Speed is defined as the distance travelled per unit time. It is a scalar quantity and is always positive or zero. Speed = Distance / Time.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Displacement per unit time defines velocity, not speed. Acceleration per unit time is the rate of change of acceleration (jerk). Force per unit mass defines acceleration. Speed is specifically distance per unit time.

questions.question_text: The SI unit of velocity is:
questions.explanation_correct: The SI unit of velocity is metre per second (m/s). Velocity is displacement (measured in metres) divided by time (measured in seconds).
questions.explanation_incorrect: m/s² is the SI unit of acceleration. km/h is a common unit but not the SI unit. m is the unit of length. The correct SI unit of velocity is m/s.

questions.question_text: A car travels 150 km in 3 hours. What is its average speed?
questions.explanation_correct: Average speed = Total distance / Total time = 150 km / 3 h = 50 km/h. The car covers an average of 50 kilometres every hour.
questions.explanation_incorrect: 450 km/h would be 150 × 3, which is incorrect. 30 km/h and 75 km/h are not obtained from the correct division. Average speed = 150 ÷ 3 = 50 km/h.

questions.question_text: A person walks 4 km north and then 3 km east in 1 hour. What is the magnitude of the average velocity?
questions.explanation_correct: Average velocity = Displacement / Time. The displacement is the hypotenuse of a right triangle with sides 4 km and 3 km: displacement = √(4² + 3²) = √(16 + 9) = √25 = 5 km. Average velocity = 5 km / 1 h = 5 km/h.
questions.explanation_incorrect: 7 km/h is the average speed (total distance/time). The average velocity uses displacement, not distance. Using Pythagoras' theorem, displacement = √(4² + 3²) = 5 km, so average velocity = 5 km/h.

questions.question_text: If an object covers equal distances in equal intervals of time, the motion is called:
questions.explanation_correct: Uniform motion is when an object covers equal distances in equal intervals of time. In such motion, the speed remains constant throughout.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Non-uniform motion involves covering unequal distances in equal time intervals. Circular and oscillatory motion are specific types of motion related to path shape. The described motion, covering equal distances in equal time, is uniform motion.

questions.question_text: What is the SI unit of acceleration?
questions.explanation_correct: The SI unit of acceleration is metre per second squared (m/s²). Acceleration is the rate of change of velocity (m/s) with respect to time (s), giving m/s² as the unit.
questions.explanation_incorrect: m/s is the unit of velocity, not acceleration. km/h is a unit of speed, and m is a unit of distance. The correct SI unit of acceleration is m/s².

questions.question_text: A car increases its velocity from 20 m/s to 40 m/s in 5 seconds. What is the acceleration?
questions.explanation_correct: Acceleration = (Final velocity − Initial velocity) / Time = (40 − 20) / 5 = 20/5 = 4 m/s². The car's velocity increases by 4 m/s every second.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Using the formula a = (v − u)/t: a = (40 − 20)/5 = 4 m/s². Options A, C, and D result from incorrect arithmetic. The correct answer is 4 m/s².

questions.question_text: An object moving with a velocity of 30 m/s is brought to rest in 6 seconds. What is the retardation?
questions.explanation_correct: Retardation is the magnitude of negative acceleration. Acceleration = (0 − 30)/6 = −5 m/s². The retardation (deceleration) is 5 m/s².
questions.explanation_incorrect: −5 m/s² is the acceleration (not retardation, which is the magnitude). Retardation = |a| = |(0 − 30)/6| = 5 m/s². 6 m/s² and 180 m/s² come from incorrect calculations.

questions.question_text: The first equation of motion is:
questions.explanation_correct: The first equation of motion is v = u + at, where v is the final velocity, u is the initial velocity, a is the acceleration, and t is the time taken. It relates velocity, acceleration, and time.
questions.explanation_incorrect: s = ut + ½at² is the second equation, v² = u² + 2as is the third equation, and F = ma is Newton's second law. The first equation of motion is v = u + at.

questions.question_text: A body starts from rest and accelerates at 2 m/s² for 10 seconds. What distance does it cover?
questions.explanation_correct: Using s = ut + ½at²: u = 0 (starts from rest), a = 2 m/s², t = 10 s. So s = 0 + ½ × 2 × 10² = 1 × 100 = 100 m.
questions.explanation_incorrect: With u = 0, s = ½at² = ½ × 2 × 100 = 100 m. Option A (20 m) forgets the square on time. Option C (200 m) misses the ½ factor. Option D (50 m) uses incorrect values.

questions.question_text: A car moving at 10 m/s accelerates uniformly at 2 m/s². What is its velocity after 5 seconds?
questions.explanation_correct: Using v = u + at: v = 10 + 2 × 5 = 10 + 10 = 20 m/s. The car's velocity after 5 seconds is 20 m/s.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Applying the first equation of motion v = u + at with u = 10, a = 2, t = 5 gives v = 20 m/s. Other options arise from arithmetic errors.

questions.question_text: A body moving with initial velocity 5 m/s accelerates uniformly and covers 60 m in 4 seconds. What is its acceleration?
questions.explanation_correct: Using s = ut + ½at²: 60 = 5(4) + ½a(16) → 60 = 20 + 8a → 8a = 40 → a = 5 m/s². The acceleration is 5 m/s².
questions.explanation_incorrect: Substituting s = 60, u = 5, t = 4 into s = ut + ½at² gives 60 = 20 + 8a, so a = 5 m/s². The other values do not satisfy this equation.

questions.question_text: A train travelling at 72 km/h applies brakes and comes to rest in 10 seconds. What is the distance covered during braking?
questions.explanation_correct: First convert 72 km/h to m/s: 72 × 5/18 = 20 m/s. Using v² = u² + 2as: 0 = 400 + 2a(s) and v = u + at: 0 = 20 + a(10), so a = −2 m/s². Then s = ut + ½at² = 20(10) + ½(−2)(100) = 200 − 100 = 100 m.
questions.explanation_incorrect: 72 km/h = 20 m/s. Using equations of motion with u = 20, v = 0, t = 10: a = −2 m/s² and s = 100 m. Other options result from not converting units or using wrong formulae.

questions.question_text: The slope of a velocity-time graph represents:
questions.explanation_correct: The slope of a velocity-time graph represents acceleration. Since acceleration is the rate of change of velocity with respect to time, and slope = change in y / change in x = Δv/Δt = acceleration.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The area under a velocity-time graph gives displacement, not the slope. The slope of a distance-time graph gives speed. The slope of a velocity-time graph specifically gives acceleration.

questions.question_text: The area under a velocity-time graph gives:
questions.explanation_correct: The area under a velocity-time graph gives the distance covered (or displacement). This is because area = velocity × time, which equals distance.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The slope of the velocity-time graph gives acceleration, not the area. The area under the curve represents the product of velocity and time, which is distance.

questions.question_text: In uniform circular motion, which quantity remains constant?
questions.explanation_correct: In uniform circular motion, the speed (magnitude of velocity) remains constant, but the velocity changes continuously because the direction of motion keeps changing along the circular path.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Velocity is not constant because its direction changes continuously. Acceleration also changes direction. The direction of motion is constantly changing. Only speed remains constant in uniform circular motion.

questions.question_text: Why is uniform circular motion called accelerated motion even though the speed is constant?

options.text: Because the direction of velocity changes continuously
Because the mass of the object changes

questions.explanation_correct: Uniform circular motion is accelerated because velocity is a vector quantity. Even though the speed is constant, the direction of velocity changes continuously, which means the velocity is changing. Any change in velocity implies acceleration.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The object does not speed up in uniform circular motion. The radius and mass remain constant. The acceleration arises because the direction of velocity keeps changing, making it a vector change even at constant speed.

questions.question_text: An athlete runs along a circular track of radius 7 m and completes one full round. What is the ratio of distance to displacement?

options.text: Distance is 44 m, displacement is 0 m

questions.explanation_correct: Distance = circumference = 2πr = 2 × 22/7 × 7 = 44 m. Displacement = 0 m because the athlete returns to the starting point. The ratio is undefined since displacement is zero.
questions.explanation_incorrect: After completing one full round, the athlete is back at the starting point, so displacement is 0. The distance covered is the circumference = 2πr = 44 m. Since displacement is zero, a finite ratio cannot be defined.

questions.question_text: A bus travels 100 km at 50 km/h and then 100 km at 25 km/h. What is the average speed for the entire journey?
questions.explanation_correct: Time for first part = 100/50 = 2 h. Time for second part = 100/25 = 4 h. Total distance = 200 km, total time = 6 h. Average speed = 200/6 = 33.3 km/h.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Average speed is not the arithmetic mean of the two speeds (which would give 37.5 km/h). It is total distance divided by total time: 200/(2 + 4) = 33.3 km/h.

questions.question_text: A body starting from rest attains a velocity of 20 m/s in 4 seconds. What is the distance covered?
questions.explanation_correct: u = 0, v = 20 m/s, t = 4 s. Using s = (u + v)t/2 = (0 + 20) × 4/2 = 40 m. Alternatively, a = 20/4 = 5 m/s², s = 0 + ½ × 5 × 16 = 40 m.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Using s = (u + v)t/2 with u = 0, v = 20, t = 4: s = (20)(4)/2 = 40 m. The other values arise from incorrect application of equations of motion.

questions.question_text: A ball is thrown vertically upward with a velocity of 20 m/s. How high will it go before stopping? (Take g = 10 m/s²)
questions.explanation_correct: At maximum height, v = 0. Using v² = u² + 2as: 0 = (20)² + 2(−10)(s) → 0 = 400 − 20s → s = 20 m. The ball reaches a height of 20 m.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Using v² = u² + 2as with v = 0, u = 20, a = −10: s = u²/(2g) = 400/20 = 20 m. The other options result from incorrect substitutions.

questions.question_text: A body moves 10 m along a straight line and returns 4 m back. What is the displacement?
questions.explanation_correct: Displacement = net change in position = 10 − 4 = 6 m (in the initial direction). The total distance would be 14 m, but displacement is only 6 m.
questions.explanation_incorrect: 14 m is the total distance, not displacement. Displacement considers the net change from start to finish: 10 − 4 = 6 m in the original direction.

questions.question_text: A car travels 120 km in the first 2 hours and 80 km in the next 2 hours. What is the average speed?
questions.explanation_correct: Total distance = 120 + 80 = 200 km. Total time = 2 + 2 = 4 hours. Average speed = 200/4 = 50 km/h.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Average speed = Total distance / Total time = 200/4 = 50 km/h. It is not the average of 60 km/h and 40 km/h (which would be 50 km/h, coincidentally the same here). The correct method always uses totals.

questions.question_text: A body with initial velocity 2 m/s has a uniform acceleration of 3 m/s². What is the velocity after covering 10 m?
questions.explanation_correct: Using v² = u² + 2as: v² = (2)² + 2(3)(10) = 4 + 60 = 64. Therefore v = √64 = 8 m/s.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Using v² = u² + 2as = 4 + 60 = 64, so v = √64 = 8 m/s. 64 m/s is v², not v. 6 m/s and 10 m/s do not satisfy the equation.

questions.question_text: An object is moving in a circular path of radius 14 m with a constant speed. It completes one revolution in 4 seconds. What is its speed?
questions.explanation_correct: Speed = Circumference / Time period = 2πr/T = 2 × 22/7 × 14 / 4 = 88/4 = 22 m/s.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Circumference = 2πr = 2 × 22/7 × 14 = 88 m. Speed = 88/4 = 22 m/s. 88 m/s uses only circumference without dividing by time. 44 m/s and 11 m/s arise from miscalculations.

questions.question_text: When a body moves with a negative acceleration, it is said to be:
questions.explanation_correct: Negative acceleration means the velocity of the body is decreasing with time. This is called deceleration or retardation. The body is slowing down.
questions.explanation_incorrect: A body with negative acceleration is not at rest (it is still moving but slowing down), not in uniform motion (its velocity is changing), and not necessarily in circular motion. It is decelerating.

questions.question_text: A distance-time graph for uniform motion is a:

options.text: Straight line parallel to time axis
Straight line with a positive slope

questions.explanation_correct: For uniform motion, equal distances are covered in equal time intervals, so the distance-time graph is a straight line with a positive slope. The slope of this line gives the speed.
questions.explanation_incorrect: A curved line indicates non-uniform motion. A line parallel to the time axis means the object is at rest. A zig-zag line is not a standard representation. Uniform motion gives a straight line with positive slope.

questions.question_text: Distance can never be negative or zero for a moving object.
questions.explanation_correct: True. Distance is a scalar quantity that measures the total path length. For a moving object, the path length is always positive and can never be negative or zero.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The statement is true. Distance is always positive for a moving object because it represents the total length of the path travelled. Unlike displacement, distance cannot be negative or zero when the object is in motion.

questions.question_text: Speed and velocity always have the same numerical value.
questions.explanation_correct: False. Speed and velocity have the same numerical value only when the object moves in a straight line without changing direction. In other cases, average speed can be different from average velocity because distance can be greater than displacement.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Speed is distance/time and velocity is displacement/time. Since distance is greater than or equal to displacement, speed can be greater than velocity. They are equal only for straight-line motion without direction change.

questions.question_text: A ball is thrown vertically upward. At the highest point, which statement is correct?

options.text: Both velocity and acceleration are zero
Velocity is zero but acceleration is non-zero
Velocity is non-zero but acceleration is zero
Both velocity and acceleration are non-zero

questions.explanation_correct: At the highest point, the ball momentarily stops, so velocity is zero. However, acceleration due to gravity (g = 9.8 m/s² downward) continues to act, so acceleration is non-zero.
questions.explanation_incorrect: At the top of its trajectory, the ball has zero velocity (it stops momentarily) but gravity still acts, giving a non-zero acceleration of 9.8 m/s² downward.

questions.question_text: In uniform circular motion, the velocity of the object is constant.
questions.explanation_correct: False. In uniform circular motion, the speed is constant but the velocity is not constant. Velocity is a vector quantity, and since the direction of motion changes continuously along the circular path, the velocity keeps changing.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The statement is false because velocity is a vector. In uniform circular motion, the speed (magnitude) stays the same, but the direction changes continuously, so the velocity is not constant.

questions.question_text: The area under a speed-time graph gives the distance covered by the object.
questions.explanation_correct: True. The area under a speed-time graph represents distance covered. This is because distance = speed × time, and the area under the curve effectively sums up speed × time for infinitely small time intervals.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The statement is true. The area under a speed-time graph gives the total distance covered, as it represents the cumulative product of speed and time.

questions.question_text: Which of the following is always true for an object in motion?
questions.explanation_correct: Distance is always greater than or equal to the magnitude of displacement. They are equal only when the object moves in a straight line without changing direction. In all other cases, distance is greater.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Distance equals displacement only in straight-line motion without reversal. In curved or back-and-forth motion, distance exceeds displacement. Displacement can never exceed distance.

questions.question_text: An object moving with uniform velocity has zero acceleration.
questions.explanation_correct: True. Acceleration is the rate of change of velocity. If velocity is uniform (constant in both magnitude and direction), then the change in velocity is zero, making acceleration zero.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The statement is true. Since acceleration = change in velocity / time, and velocity is not changing (uniform), the acceleration must be zero.

questions.question_text: The shortest distance between the initial and final position of an object is called ___.
questions.explanation_correct: Displacement is defined as the shortest distance measured from the initial to the final position of an object. It is a vector quantity having both magnitude and direction.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct answer is 'displacement'. Distance is the total path length, not the shortest distance. Displacement specifically refers to the shortest straight-line distance between start and end points.

questions.question_text: The rate of change of displacement with respect to time is called ___.
questions.explanation_correct: Velocity is defined as the rate of change of displacement with time. It is a vector quantity with both magnitude (speed) and direction. Velocity = Displacement / Time.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct answer is 'velocity', not 'speed'. Speed is the rate of change of distance with time. Velocity specifically uses displacement, making it a vector quantity.

questions.question_text: The rate of change of velocity with respect to time is called ___.
questions.explanation_correct: Acceleration is defined as the rate of change of velocity with respect to time. Its SI unit is m/s². Acceleration = (Change in velocity) / Time.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct answer is 'acceleration'. It measures how quickly the velocity of an object changes over time. The SI unit is m/s².

questions.question_text: Which equation of motion relates displacement, initial velocity, acceleration, and time?
questions.explanation_correct: The second equation of motion, s = ut + ½at², relates displacement (s), initial velocity (u), acceleration (a), and time (t). This equation does not involve final velocity.
questions.explanation_incorrect: v = u + at relates v, u, a, t but not s. v² = u² + 2as relates v, u, a, s but not t. The equation involving s, u, a, and t is s = ut + ½at².

questions.question_text: When an object moves along a circular path with constant speed, the motion is called uniform ___ motion.
questions.explanation_correct: Uniform circular motion is the motion of an object along a circular path at constant speed. Although speed is constant, velocity changes due to continuous change in direction.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct answer is 'circular'. Uniform circular motion specifically describes an object moving at constant speed along a circular path.

questions.question_text: To convert a speed of 72 km/h into m/s, the result is:
questions.explanation_correct: To convert km/h to m/s, multiply by 5/18. So 72 × 5/18 = 72 × 5 / 18 = 360/18 = 20 m/s.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The conversion factor from km/h to m/s is 5/18. 72 × 5/18 = 20 m/s. Multiplying by 1/10 gives 7.2 (wrong). 72 m/s would mean no conversion.

questions.question_text: The slope of a distance-time graph gives the ___ of the object.
questions.explanation_correct: The slope of a distance-time graph gives the speed of the object. Since slope = change in distance / change in time = speed, a steeper slope indicates higher speed.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct answer is 'speed'. The slope of a distance-time graph equals distance/time, which is the definition of speed.

questions.question_text: A bicycle changes its velocity from 0 to 10 m/s in 5 s and then from 10 m/s to 15 m/s in the next 5 s. Which statement is correct?

options.text: Acceleration is same in both intervals
Acceleration in the first interval is greater
Acceleration in the second interval is greater
There is no acceleration in either interval

questions.explanation_correct: First interval: a₁ = (10 − 0)/5 = 2 m/s². Second interval: a₂ = (15 − 10)/5 = 1 m/s². Since 2 > 1, the acceleration in the first interval is greater.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Acceleration = change in velocity / time. First: (10 − 0)/5 = 2 m/s². Second: (15 − 10)/5 = 1 m/s². The acceleration is different and greater in the first interval.

questions.question_text: A stone is dropped from a height of 80 m. How long does it take to reach the ground? (Take g = 10 m/s²)
questions.explanation_correct: Using s = ut + ½gt²: 80 = 0 + ½(10)t² → 80 = 5t² → t² = 16 → t = 4 s. The stone takes 4 seconds to reach the ground.
questions.explanation_incorrect: With u = 0, s = 80 m, g = 10 m/s²: s = ½gt² → t = √(2s/g) = √(160/10) = √16 = 4 s. Other options arise from incorrect calculations.

questions.question_text: Can the average velocity of an object be zero even when its average speed is non-zero?

options.text: Yes, when the object returns to its starting point
Yes, only when the object is at rest

questions.explanation_correct: Yes. When an object returns to its starting point, the displacement is zero, making average velocity zero. However, the distance covered is non-zero, so average speed is non-zero. This can happen in any path, not just circular motion.
questions.explanation_incorrect: It is possible for average velocity to be zero while average speed is non-zero. This happens whenever the object returns to its starting point — the displacement becomes zero (so velocity is zero) but distance is non-zero (so speed is non-zero). This is not limited to circular motion.

questions.question_text: A car starting from rest accelerates at 5 m/s² for 4 s and then moves with constant velocity. What is the distance covered in the first 6 seconds?
questions.explanation_correct: Phase 1 (0-4 s): s₁ = 0 + ½(5)(16) = 40 m, final velocity = 0 + 5(4) = 20 m/s. Phase 2 (4-6 s): s₂ = 20 × 2 = 40 m. Total distance = 40 + 40 = 80 m.
questions.explanation_incorrect: In the first 4 s, distance = ½(5)(16) = 40 m and v = 20 m/s. In the next 2 s at constant velocity: distance = 20 × 2 = 40 m. Total = 80 m.

questions.question_text: A body moves along a semicircular path of radius 7 m. What is the ratio of distance covered to the magnitude of displacement?
questions.explanation_correct: Distance = half circumference = πr = 22/7 × 7 = 22 m. Displacement = diameter = 2r = 14 m. Ratio = 22/14 = 11/7.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Distance along semicircle = πr = 22 m. Displacement = diameter = 14 m. Ratio = distance/displacement = 22/14 = 11/7. Option A (7/22) and C (7/11) are inverses of the correct values. Option D (22/7) equals π, which is the ratio of circumference to diameter for a full circle, not the distance-to-displacement ratio for a semicircle.

questions.question_text: How does distance differ from displacement in terms of the path taken by an object?

options.text: Distance measures the shortest path; displacement measures the actual path
Distance measures the actual path length; displacement measures the shortest straight-line separation between start and end points
Both measure the actual path length but in different units
Distance and displacement are identical for all types of motion

questions.explanation_correct: Distance is the total length of the actual path travelled by an object (scalar, always positive), whereas displacement is the shortest straight-line distance from the initial to the final position (vector, can be positive, negative, or zero). They differ fundamentally in what path information they capture.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Option A reverses the definitions. Option C is wrong because both use the same unit (metre) but measure different things. Option D is false because distance equals displacement only for straight-line motion without reversal.

questions.question_text: How does speed differ from velocity in terms of the physical quantity each involves?

options.text: Speed uses displacement; velocity uses distance
Speed is always greater than velocity
Speed is the rate of change of distance (scalar); velocity is the rate of change of displacement (vector)
Speed has direction; velocity does not

questions.explanation_correct: Speed is defined as distance covered per unit time and is a scalar quantity (magnitude only). Velocity is defined as displacement per unit time and is a vector quantity (has both magnitude and direction). This is the fundamental difference between the two.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Option A reverses the definitions. Option B is not always true — for straight-line motion without reversal, speed equals the magnitude of velocity. Option D reverses the scalar/vector nature. Speed is scalar; velocity is vector.

questions.question_text: How does uniform motion differ from non-uniform motion in terms of the velocity-time graph?

options.text: Uniform motion gives a curved line; non-uniform motion gives a straight horizontal line
Uniform motion gives a straight horizontal line (zero slope); non-uniform motion gives a line with non-zero slope or a curve
Both give identical straight lines on a velocity-time graph
Uniform motion cannot be represented on a velocity-time graph

questions.explanation_correct: In uniform motion the velocity is constant, so the velocity-time graph is a straight horizontal line (slope = 0, meaning zero acceleration). In non-uniform motion the velocity changes with time, producing either a sloped straight line (uniform acceleration) or a curve (non-uniform acceleration).
questions.explanation_incorrect: Option A reverses the descriptions. Option C is wrong because the two types of motion produce distinctly different graphs. Option D is incorrect — uniform motion is simply a horizontal line on the v-t graph.

questions.question_text: How does the distance-time graph of a uniformly accelerated body differ from that of a body moving with uniform speed?

options.text: Uniform speed gives a parabola; uniform acceleration gives a straight line
Both give straight lines with different slopes
Uniform speed gives a straight line with constant slope; uniform acceleration gives a curve (parabola) with increasing slope
There is no difference between the two graphs

questions.explanation_correct: For uniform speed, equal distances are covered in equal times, so the distance-time graph is a straight line with a constant slope. For uniformly accelerated motion, the distance increases as t², producing a parabolic curve whose slope (speed) increases with time.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Option A reverses the shapes. Option B is wrong because only uniform speed gives a straight line; accelerated motion gives a curve. Option D is incorrect because the shapes are fundamentally different.

questions.question_text: How does uniform circular motion differ from uniform linear motion in terms of acceleration?

options.text: Both have zero acceleration since speed is constant in each case
Uniform linear motion has zero acceleration; uniform circular motion has non-zero acceleration because the direction of velocity keeps changing
Uniform linear motion has non-zero acceleration; uniform circular motion has zero acceleration

questions.explanation_correct: In uniform linear motion, both the magnitude and direction of velocity remain constant, so acceleration is zero. In uniform circular motion, although speed is constant, the direction of velocity changes continuously, producing a non-zero acceleration directed towards the centre of the circle.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Option A wrongly assumes that constant speed always means zero acceleration. Option C reverses the facts. Option D is wrong because uniform linear motion truly has zero acceleration. The key is that velocity is a vector — a change in direction also counts as acceleration.

questions.question_text: A quantity related to motion has magnitude only, is always non-negative, and depends on the actual path taken. This quantity is:
questions.explanation_correct: Distance is a scalar quantity (magnitude only), is always non-negative for a moving object, and depends on the actual path taken. These three features together uniquely identify distance. Displacement, by contrast, is a vector that can be negative or zero and depends only on start and end positions, not the path.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Displacement is a vector (has direction) and can be negative or zero, so it does not match. Velocity and acceleration are also vectors. Only distance has all three stated properties.

questions.question_text: An object's velocity changes from 10 m/s to 10 m/s over 5 seconds, but its direction changes from east to north. This motion should be classified as:

options.text: Uniform motion, because the speed is constant
Non-uniform motion, because the velocity has changed due to change in direction
Motion at rest, because the speed did not change
Uniform acceleration, because the speed is the same at start and end

questions.explanation_correct: Uniform motion requires constant velocity, which means both magnitude and direction must remain the same. Here, although the speed (magnitude) stays at 10 m/s, the direction changes from east to north. Since velocity is a vector, this change in direction means the velocity has changed, making the motion non-uniform.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Option A confuses speed with velocity — constant speed does not mean constant velocity if direction changes. Option C is wrong because the object is clearly moving. Option D is not valid reasoning; having the same speed at two points does not define uniform acceleration.

questions.question_text: On a velocity-time graph, a straight line passing through the origin with a positive slope represents motion that is classified as:

options.text: Uniformly accelerated motion starting from rest

questions.explanation_correct: A straight line on a velocity-time graph indicates constant (uniform) acceleration, since the slope (which represents acceleration) is constant. The line passes through the origin, meaning velocity is zero at time zero — the body starts from rest. A positive slope means the velocity is increasing. Together, these features classify the motion as uniformly accelerated motion starting from rest.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Option A would be a horizontal line (zero slope). Option C would give a curve, not a straight line. Option D would have a negative slope. A straight line through the origin with positive slope uniquely represents uniformly accelerated motion from rest.

questions.question_text: A physical quantity is defined as the rate of change of displacement with time, has both magnitude and direction, and its SI unit is m/s. This quantity is classified as:
questions.explanation_correct: Velocity is defined as displacement per unit time, is a vector quantity (has both magnitude and direction), and its SI unit is m/s. All three features match velocity. Speed also has the unit m/s but is a scalar and uses distance, not displacement.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Speed is scalar and uses distance, not displacement. Distance is measured in metres and is not a rate. Acceleration has the unit m/s², not m/s. Only velocity matches all three given features.

questions.question_text: Riya cycles from her home to school, covering 3 km in 15 minutes. She then cycles back home along the same route in 15 minutes. What are her average speed and average velocity for the entire trip?

options.text: Average speed = 6 km/h, Average velocity = 6 km/h
Average speed = 6 km/h, Average velocity = 0 km/h
Average speed = 0 km/h, Average velocity = 0 km/h
Average speed = 12 km/h, Average velocity = 0 km/h

questions.explanation_correct: Total distance = 3 + 3 = 6 km. Total time = 15 + 15 = 30 min = 0.5 h. Average speed = 6/0.5 = 12 km/h. Since Riya returns to her starting point, displacement = 0 km, so average velocity = 0/0.5 = 0 km/h. Therefore, average speed is 12 km/h and average velocity is 0 km/h.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Option A and B incorrectly give average speed as 6 km/h. The total distance is 6 km and total time is 0.5 h, so average speed = 6/0.5 = 12 km/h, not 6 km/h. Option C is wrong because the object did move, so average speed cannot be zero. Displacement is 0 (returns to start), so average velocity = 0 km/h.

questions.question_text: Amit drops a ball from the balcony of his apartment, 45 m above the ground. Taking g = 10 m/s², how long does the ball take to reach the ground?
questions.explanation_correct: The ball is dropped (u = 0) from height s = 45 m with g = 10 m/s². Using s = ut + ½gt²: 45 = 0 + ½(10)t² = 5t². So t² = 9, giving t = 3 s. The ball takes 3 seconds to reach the ground.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Using s = ½gt² with u = 0: 45 = 5t², t² = 9, t = 3 s. Option B (4.5 s) results from dividing 45 by 10 without using the correct formula. Option C (9 s) confuses t² with t. Option D (2.5 s) does not satisfy the equation.

questions.question_text: Priya is on a train that accelerates uniformly from rest. She notices that the train covers 50 m in the first 10 seconds. What is the acceleration of the train?
questions.explanation_correct: The train starts from rest, so u = 0. Using s = ut + ½at²: 50 = 0 + ½a(10²) = 50a. Therefore a = 50/50 = 1 m/s². The train accelerates at 1 m/s².
questions.explanation_incorrect: With u = 0, s = 50 m, t = 10 s: 50 = ½a(100) = 50a, so a = 1 m/s². Option A (5 m/s²) comes from dividing 50 by 10. Option C and D do not satisfy the equation of motion.

questions.question_text: Rohan runs around a rectangular playground that is 80 m long and 60 m wide, starting and finishing at the same corner. What are the distance covered and the displacement?
questions.explanation_correct: The perimeter of the rectangle = 2(80 + 60) = 2 × 140 = 280 m. This is the total distance Rohan covers. Since he starts and finishes at the same corner, the displacement is 0 m (initial and final positions are the same).
questions.explanation_incorrect: Option A wrongly gives a non-zero displacement. Option C halves the perimeter. Option D equates displacement with distance. Since Rohan returns to the starting point, displacement = 0 m, and the full perimeter = 280 m.

questions.question_text: Meera is driving on a highway at 54 km/h when she spots a stop sign 37.5 m ahead and applies brakes, decelerating uniformly. If she stops exactly at the sign, what is the magnitude of her deceleration?
questions.explanation_correct: First convert 54 km/h to m/s: 54 × 5/18 = 15 m/s. Using v² = u² + 2as with v = 0: 0 = 15² + 2a(37.5) = 225 + 75a. So a = −225/75 = −3 m/s². The magnitude of deceleration is 3 m/s².
questions.explanation_incorrect: 54 km/h = 15 m/s. Using v² = u² + 2as: 0 = 225 + 75a, a = −3 m/s². The deceleration magnitude is 3 m/s². Option A uses wrong arithmetic. Option C and D do not satisfy the equation.

questions.question_text: Which of the following is actually an example of accelerated motion?

options.text: A car moving at 60 km/h on a straight highway
A train moving at constant speed on a straight track
A cyclist moving at constant speed along a circular roundabout
A ball rolling at constant speed on a straight flat surface

questions.explanation_correct: A cyclist moving at constant speed along a circular roundabout is in uniform circular motion. Although the speed is constant, the direction of velocity changes continuously, which means the velocity is changing. Any change in velocity constitutes acceleration. This is the exception that students often miss — constant speed does NOT always mean zero acceleration.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Options A, B, and D all describe motion at constant speed in a straight line, where both speed and direction remain unchanged, so velocity is constant and acceleration is zero. Only option C involves a change in direction, making it accelerated despite constant speed.

questions.question_text: In which of the following cases is the magnitude of displacement actually equal to the distance covered?

options.text: A runner completing one lap around a 400 m track
A ball thrown vertically up and caught back at the same height
An auto-rickshaw taking a U-turn on a road
A stone sliding 5 m down a straight frictionless ramp without changing direction

questions.explanation_correct: Displacement equals distance only when an object moves in a straight line without changing direction. In option D, the stone slides straight down the ramp in one direction, so distance = displacement = 5 m. In all other options, the object changes direction at some point, making distance greater than displacement.
questions.explanation_incorrect: In option A, the runner returns to the start (displacement = 0, distance = 400 m). In option B, the ball returns to the same height (displacement = 0). In option C, a U-turn reverses direction. Only in option D does the object move in a single straight-line direction, keeping distance equal to displacement.

questions.question_text: Which of the following situations actually represents zero acceleration?

options.text: A ball rolling down an inclined plane
A satellite orbiting Earth at constant speed
A car moving at 40 km/h in a straight line on a level road
A stone thrown vertically upward at its highest point

questions.explanation_correct: A car moving at constant speed in a straight line has constant velocity (both magnitude and direction unchanged), so acceleration is zero. Options A and D involve gravitational acceleration. Option B involves continuous change in direction (circular orbit), which means non-zero centripetal acceleration despite constant speed. Students often mistakenly think the stone at its highest point has zero acceleration, but gravity still acts on it.
questions.explanation_incorrect: A ball on an incline accelerates due to gravity. A satellite in orbit has centripetal acceleration. A stone at its highest point still has gravitational acceleration (g = 9.8 m/s² downward) even though its velocity is momentarily zero. Only the car moving at constant speed in a straight line has zero acceleration.

questions.question_text: Why is uniform circular motion classified as accelerated motion and not uniform motion?

options.text: Because the object covers unequal distances in equal time intervals
Because the speed of the object keeps increasing
Because velocity is a vector, and the continuous change in direction means velocity is changing even though speed is constant
Because the radius of the circular path keeps changing

questions.explanation_correct: Uniform circular motion involves constant speed, so the object does cover equal distances in equal time intervals. However, velocity is a vector quantity — it has both magnitude and direction. In circular motion, the direction of motion changes at every point on the path. Since velocity changes (even though only its direction changes), there is a non-zero acceleration. Therefore, it is classified as accelerated motion.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Option A is incorrect because in uniform circular motion, equal distances are covered in equal time intervals (speed is constant). Option B is wrong because speed remains constant. Option D is wrong because the radius stays the same. The reason is that velocity is a vector and its direction changes continuously.

questions.question_text: Why does the area under a velocity-time graph give the distance covered, rather than the velocity or acceleration?

options.text: Because the slope of the graph gives distance
Because the area has the dimensions of velocity × time = (m/s) × s = m, which is the dimension of distance
Because the graph is always a straight line
Because distance is always plotted on the y-axis

questions.explanation_correct: The area under a velocity-time graph is calculated as the product of the y-axis quantity (velocity, in m/s) and the x-axis quantity (time, in s). The resulting dimension is (m/s) × s = m, which is the dimension of length or distance. This is why the area gives distance, not velocity or acceleration.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Option A is wrong — the slope of a v-t graph gives acceleration, not distance. Option C is irrelevant; the graph can be a curve for non-uniform acceleration. Option D is wrong because velocity, not distance, is plotted on the y-axis. The correct reason is the dimensional analysis: velocity × time = distance.

questions.question_text: Why can the average speed of an object never be negative, while the average velocity can be?

options.text: Because speed is measured in km/h while velocity is measured in m/s
Because speed is calculated using distance (always non-negative) and time (always positive), while velocity uses displacement which can be negative
Because speed is always larger than velocity
Because negative speed has no practical meaning in physics

questions.explanation_correct: Average speed = total distance / total time. Distance is always non-negative (it is a scalar measuring path length) and time is always positive, so their ratio can never be negative. Average velocity = displacement / time. Displacement is a vector that can be positive, negative, or zero depending on direction, so velocity can also be negative.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Option A is wrong — both can be expressed in either unit. Option C is not always true and does not explain the sign. Option D is circular reasoning. The actual reason is that distance (used for speed) is always non-negative, while displacement (used for velocity) can be negative.
